title: Mysterious polio-like disease targeting kids may be caused by 'missing' virus, study says
text:
CLOSE Health officials say an illness that in rare cases causes a polio-like condition has been reported in various states around the country. AP

Scientists think they finally have an answer to the mysterious acute flaccid myelitis, the polio-like illness that causes paralysis in children, also known as AFM.

A new study conducted by researchers at the University of California, San Francisco, and published Monday in the peer-reviewed journal Nature Medicine, suggests that the devastating disease could be caused by a strain of a respiratory virus called enterovirus.

AFM cases are exceedingly rare; fewer than one in a million children are affected. But for a small number of children, the results are devastating.

It can paralyze a child's arms and legs. Some need ventilators to breathe. It can also cause muscle weakness, slurred speech and difficulty moving eyes and swallowing.

Many scientists attempted to find the "missing" virus in the spinal fluid but failed with traditional testing methods. Experts remained skeptical after the virus couldn’t be found in 98% of AFM patients, later proposing that the disease may have been caused by an autoimmune disorder.

Attention parents: What you should know about the polio-like paralyzing disease the CDC is warning about

“If we could detect something specific to a virus in the spinal fluid of AFM patients, we would feel more secure claiming that the neurologic symptoms of the disease are virally mediated,” said Michael Wilson, MD, associate professor of neurology at UCSF and senior author of the study.

And that’s exactly what the group of researchers set out to do.

Wilson’s team, in collaboration with the Chan Zuckerberg Biohub, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the California Department of Public Health, obtained the spinal fluid from 42 children with AFM.

Using an enhanced version of the virus-hunting tool called VirScan, they were able to find antibodies against the enterovirus in nearly 70% of the patients.

“The strength of this study is not just what was found, but also what was not found,” said co-author Joe DeRisi, PhD, professor of biochemistry and biophysics at UCSF. “Enterovirus antibodies were the only ones enriched in AFM patients. No other viral family showed elevated antibody levels.”

Questions unanswered: Acute flaccid myelitis strikes active 4-year-old. But doctors don't know why he got the polio-like disease.

Although this study may have solved the case of the “missing virus,” the study acknowledges that many questions remain unanswered.

For example, the strains of enteroviruses that were detected in the spinal fluid – EV-D68 and EV-A71 – have never been able to cause paralysis until now. Wilson says that the D68 strain has been linked to the most severe cases of AFM.

"There's ongoing work to determine if some genetic changes in the virus over the last few years may have made it more prone to causing this polio-like illness," he told USA TODAY Tuesday.

Wilson also points out that although antibodies for the virus were present, the team was unable to find the actual virus and prove that it's the causing agent to AFM.

Priya Duggal, associate professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, says another question that needs answering is why only a subset of children are developing AFM even though the enterovirus can be detected in thousands of kids.

"This is about what causes AFM," Duggal told USA TODAY. "Even if we find the causative pathogen, something else is happening that we don’t understand."

Although more research is needed, both Wilson and Duggal say that a logical next step should include research into antiviral drugs — and possibly even developing a vaccine.

Nearly 600 cases in 48 states and D.C. have been confirmed in the U.S. since 2014, with 20 cases confirmed in 2019, according to the CDC.

Contributing: Ken Alltucker, USA TODAY. Follow Adrianna Rodriguez on Twitter: @AdriannaUSAT.
